Early-blight.title: Early Blight (Alternaria solani)
Early-blight.short_description: Early blight is a fungal disease that causes dark, concentric ring spots on older leaves, leading to yellowing and premature leaf drop.
symptoms: Brown to black circular spots with concentric rings (target-like appearance)
Starts on lower, older leaves and moves upward
Yellowing and drying of leaves around spots
Stem lesions near soil line and fruit rot on green fruit
causes: Caused by fungus Alternaria solani
Favored by warm (75–85°F), humid weather and prolonged leaf wetness
Spreads via wind, rain splash, and infected debris

treatment_steps.details: Prune and dispose of affected leaves early to slow disease spread.
Use chlorothalonil or mancozeb-based fungicides every 7–10 days. Examples: Daconil, Mancozeb Flowable.
Choose cultivars labeled 'EBR' (Early Blight Resistant).
Apply straw mulch to prevent soil splash and stake plants for air movement.
Avoid planting tomatoes or potatoes in the same area for 2–3 years.

prevention: Remove debris at end of season
organic_solutions: Neem oil sprays for mild infections

external_resources.title: University of Minnesota Extension - Early Blight

images.description: Concentric ring lesions on tomato leaf

Early-blight.warning: Fungicides work best when applied preventively. Remove infected tissue immediately.

Late-blight.title: Late Blight (Phytophthora infestans)
Late-blight.short_description: Late blight is a devastating oomycete disease that causes dark, water-soaked lesions on leaves, stems, and fruit, often killing plants rapidly.
symptoms: Large, irregular dark-green to brown water-soaked spots
White fungal growth on undersides of leaves in humid conditions
Rapid collapse of foliage and stems
Brown, firm rot on fruit with grayish-white mold
causes: Caused by Phytophthora infestans (same pathogen as potato blight)
Spreads via wind, rain, and infected plant material
Favored by cool (60–75°F) and wet weather

treatment_steps.details: Uproot and destroy infected plants to prevent further spread.
Use chlorothalonil or copper-based fungicides. Apply every 5–7 days during wet weather.
Use drip irrigation and water early in the morning to reduce humidity.
Remove plant debris and weeds that host the pathogen.

prevention: Rotate crops for 3 years or more
Late-blight.estimated_recovery_time: Difficult to recover; early intervention critical
Late-blight.warning: Highly contagious and can destroy crops in days. Monitor daily in humid weather.

Leaf-mold.title: Leaf Mold (Passalora fulva / Cladosporium fulvum)
Leaf-mold.short_description: Leaf mold affects primarily the foliage, appearing as yellow spots on top and olive-green fuzzy mold underneath.
symptoms: Pale green to yellow spots on upper leaf surface
Olive-green to gray mold growth under leaves
Leaves curl, wither, and drop prematurely
Rarely affects fruit under normal conditions
causes: Caused by fungus Passalora fulva (Cladosporium fulvum)
Favored by high humidity (>85%) and poor ventilation
Spread by air currents, tools, and water splash

treatment_steps.details: Increase ventilation in greenhouses; prune dense foliage.
Use chlorothalonil, mancozeb, or copper-based fungicides weekly.
Select cultivars with Cf resistance genes (e.g., Cf-2, Cf-5).
Dispose of infected foliage and avoid overhead watering.

Leaf-mold.warning: Thrives in humid greenhouses — manage ventilation carefully.

Mosaic-virus.title: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV)
Mosaic-virus.short_description: A viral disease causing mottled yellow-green leaves, distortion, and stunted growth.
symptoms: Mottled (light and dark green) leaf patterns
Distorted or fern-like leaf shapes
Reduced fruit size and uneven ripening
No mold or rot — symptoms purely visual
causes: Caused by Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) or Tobacco mosaic virus (TMV)
Spread mechanically through hands, tools, and infected plant debris
Virus can persist in soil and tools for months

treatment_steps.details: Destroy infected plants immediately to stop spread.
Use 10% bleach or 70% alcohol after handling infected material.
Select varieties labeled 'ToMV-resistant'.
Avoid planting solanaceous crops in the same area for 2 years.

prevention: Avoid smoking near plants (TMV can transmit from tobacco)
organic_solutions: Seaweed extract sprays for plant recovery
Neem oil as mild antiviral deterrent
chemical_solutions: No chemical cure — only preventive sanitation measures
Mosaic-virus.warning: Extremely persistent on tools and hands — strict hygiene required.

Septoria-leaf-spot.title: Septoria Leaf Spot (Septoria lycopersici)
Septoria-leaf-spot.short_description: A common fungal disease causing numerous small, circular brown leaf spots leading to defoliation.
symptoms: Small, circular brown spots with light centers (1–3 mm)
Dark margins around spots
Leaves yellow and drop prematurely
Usually starts on lower leaves first
causes: Caused by fungus Septoria lycopersici
Favored by wet, humid conditions and overhead watering
Spreads through splashing water and infected debris

treatment_steps.details: Prune affected foliage to reduce spore spread.
Spray chlorothalonil or copper-based fungicides every 7–10 days.
Stake plants and maintain spacing.
Do not plant tomatoes or peppers in the same soil for 2 years.

prevention: Use clean seed and resistant varieties

images.description: Small brown spots with light centers

Septoria-leaf-spot.warning: Rapidly spreads under humid conditions — begin fungicide early.

Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.title: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV)
Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.short_description: A viral disease transmitted by whiteflies that causes leaf curling, yellowing, and stunted growth.
symptoms: Upward curling and yellowing of leaves
Stunted growth and reduced fruiting
Thick, leathery leaves with crinkled texture
Flower drop and poor fruit set
causes: Caused by Tomato yellow leaf curl virus (TYLCV)
Transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci)
Spreads rapidly in warm, dry conditions

treatment_steps.details: Use yellow sticky traps and neem oil sprays. Introduce beneficial insects like Encarsia formosa.
Uproot and destroy affected plants immediately.
Choose TYLCV-tolerant hybrids (e.g., ‘Tyking’, ‘Tylcv-Res’).
Use fine mesh screens to block whiteflies in greenhouses.

prevention: Use reflective mulches to deter insects
Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.estimated_recovery_time: No cure; focus on vector control and prevention

external_resources.title: UC IPM - Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus

Yellow-leaf-curl-virus.warning: Highly contagious viral disease — focus on vector (whitefly) management.

Bacterial-spot.title: Bacterial Spot (Xanthomonas spp.)
Bacterial-spot.short_description: Bacterial spot is a serious disease affecting tomato leaves, stems, and fruit, causing small dark spots with yellow halos.
symptoms: Small, dark brown to black spots on leaves (1-3mm diameter)
Yellow halo around spots as they age
Spots may coalesce, causing large necrotic areas
Fruit shows small, raised dark spots with white halos
Severe defoliation in advanced stages
causes: Caused by Xanthomonas bacteria (X. euvesicatoria, X. gardneri, X. perforans, X. vesicatoria)
Spreads through water splash, wind-driven rain, and contaminated tools
Favored by warm (75-86°F), humid conditions
Enters through stomata and wounds

treatment_steps.action: Remove and destroy infected plant material
treatment_steps.details: Immediately remove severely infected leaves and plants. Bag and dispose of them (do not compost). Disinfect tools with 10% bleach solution between cuts.
Spray copper hydroxide or copper sulfate fungicides every 7-10 days. Apply in early morning when leaves are dry. Products: Kocide 3000, Bonide Copper Fungicide.
Apply Bacillus subtilis or Streptomyces lydicus-based products. Examples: Serenade, Actinovate. Can be used in organic farming.
Space plants properly (24-36 inches apart), use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering, mulch to prevent soil splash, and avoid working with wet plants.
Do not plant tomatoes or peppers in the same location for at least 2-3 years. Rotate with non-susceptible crops like corn, beans, or squash.

prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds and transplants
Choose resistant varieties (varieties with bacterial spot resistance)
Avoid overhead irrigation; use drip systems
Maintain good air circulation between plants
Remove plant debris at end of season
Apply preventive copper sprays in high-risk periods
organic_solutions: Copper-based bactericides (allowed in organic farming in limited amounts)
chemical_solutions: Streptomycin (in some regions, check local regulations)
Always follow label instructions and pre-harvest intervals
Bacterial-spot.estimated_recovery_time: 2-4 weeks with proper treatment; severe infections may require plant removal

external_resources.title: University of Florida IFAS - Bacterial Spot Management

Bacterial-spot.warning: Bacterial spot is difficult to control once established. Prevention and early detection are critical. Copper sprays have limited effectiveness once symptoms appear.

Healthy.title: Healthy Tomato Plant
Healthy.short_description: Your tomato plant appears healthy with no signs of disease.
maintenance_tips: Continue regular watering (1-2 inches per week)
Fertilize every 2-3 weeks with balanced fertilizer
Monitor for early signs of pests or diseases
Prune suckers for better air circulation
Mulch around plants to conserve moisture
Provide support with stakes or cages
prevention: Inspect plants weekly for early disease detection
Remove weeds that compete for nutrients

optimal_conditions.watering: 1-2 inches per week, more during fruiting
